But wait‚Ä¶ Make sure not to forget your Winter Permit! #DYK? Glacier National Park is home to the world‚Äôs largest mobile avalanche control program! Together with the Canadian Armed Forces, Parks Canada conducts avalanche control with artillery to ensure safety of transportation throughout the park, resulting in daily openings and closures. In approximately 30 locations across Ivvavik National Park, Parks Canada installs weatherproof motion-triggered wildlife cameras. Resource Conservation Officers primarily use this data to monitor grizzly bear activity in the park, especially during the caribou migration, and to learn what other animals may be active in the area.

Inner Bay of Fundy Atlantic salmon have lived for thousands of years in the Bay of Fundy, connecting forests to the ocean! üêü However, wild salmon have disappeared from the region, leaving the population at risk of extinction. This #WildlifeWednesday learn how Parks Canada is working with its partners to bring Atlantic salmon back to Fundy National Park rivers: http://ow.ly/fhh730gVbJ3

During the First World War, Winnipeg native Christopher O‚ÄôKelly (1895-1922) enlisted with the 144th Battalion (Winnipeg Rifles) and later transferred to the 52nd Infantry Battalion. In October 1917, O‚ÄôKelly led his troops in capturing enemy positions and guns near Passchendaele, Belgium, and resisting fierce counterattacks for which he was bestowed the Victoria Cross. O‚ÄôKelly returned home to a hero‚Äôs welcome in 1918. Only a few years later, while on a prospecting trip, he was lost on a lake in northern Ontario during a storm. Canada Remembers

Before enlisting in the Great War, British-born George Pearkes (1888-1984) immigrated to Alberta and served with the Royal North-West Mounted Police (forerunner of the RCMP). In 1915, he enlisted with the 2nd Canadian Mounted Rifles in British Columbia. Pearkes was awarded the Victoria Cross at Passchendaele, Belgium, in October 1917 ‚ÄúFor most conspicuous bravery and skilful handling of the troops under his command‚Äù. He continued to serve during the Second World War then began a long career in politics. Canada Remembers

Polar bears are fast sprinters! When trotting along, they can travel at a pace of 30 km/hr, and can sprint at nearly 50 km/hr! üò≤ To put that into comparison‚Ä¶ the fastest human sprinters can run at just over 35km/hr. #PolarBearWeek Polar Bears International

Did you know? Whooping cranes are the tallest birds in North America! They can stand up to 1.5 m tall, and have wingspan of 2 m or more. You can find them in Canada in remote boggy reaches of Wood Buffalo National Park of Canada. #WildlifeWednesday #DYK

Learn more about this cool #SpeciesAtRisk: http://ow.ly/e6Bg30gofLC

100 years ago, three years into the Great War, the British imperial forces launched a campaign against the enemy in Flanders, Belgium. They were later joined by the Canadian Corps who, although pressed for time, thoroughly prepared and mounted an attack on October 26. Slogging through thick mud and intense enemy fire, they succeed in capturing Passchendaele Ridge on November 10th, but at great cost: nearly 16,000 Canadians were killed, wounded or went missing. Canada Remembers

Happy Halloween! Did you know it‚Äôs also the last day of Bat Week??

As part of a landscape restoration project at Georgian Bay Islands National Park, staff needed to find out if bats were taking up residence in an old maintenance shed. The park‚Äôs Resource Conservation team used an ultrasonic acoustic detector and found Little Brown Bats sleeping in the building. They were able to determine exactly when the bats moved out in the fall, so while the bats were away for winter vacation down south, staff installed 'bat boxes' all around the area so they had nice new homes to move into when they returned in the spring. #BatWeek

Did you know the Massasauga Rattlesnakeüêç is one of Canada's most unusual snakes and one of the most threatened! This solitary, passive and timid rattlesnake relies on camouflage to avoid detection, shaking its tail in warning when it feels threatened.

Preferring flight to confrontation, it rarely strikes, doesn't pursue people and doesn't always inject venom when it bites. #WildlifeWednesday

What is the tallest bird in North America? The Whooping Crane can grow up to 4.9 ft with a 7.5 ft wingspan. 

A record number of the endangered whooping cranes was found in Wood Buffalo National Park during the 2017 nesting survey carried out with the Canadian Wildlife Service. This year‚Äôs survey found 98 nests, an increase of 16 over the previous record of 82 set in 2014!

Fire crews continue to do everything possible to slow the progress of the wildfire and protect critical infrastructure, park resources, and the community of Waterton.

Kenow Fire Information Update ‚Äì Unified Command: September 11, 2017; 19:15 

FIRE MOVEMENT AND BEHAVIOUR 
‚Ä¢ Fire is now firmly established in the Cameron Valley along the Akamina Parkway. 
‚Ä¢ There is also fire in the Tamarack Basin which is expected to grow and move into the Blakiston Valley and towards the Red Rock Parkway. 
‚Ä¢ We continue to monitor the fire progress. 
‚Ä¢ Structural protection units will be activated if necessary. 
‚Ä¢ Extensive infrastructure and facility protection is installed within the townsite including high volume pump and sprinkler systems around the perimeter of town. 
‚Ä¢ Highways 5 and 6 are now closed at the boundaries of Waterton Lakes National Park. 
‚Ä¢ We are expecting similar weather and intense fire behaviour tomorrow. 

SMOKE 
‚Ä¢ Intense fire behaviour is generating significant smoke. Wind direction and temperature inversions may result in low-lying smoke in areas north of Waterton, especially at night. 
‚Ä¢ Exercise caution while driving in the area, especially at night. Check AB 511 for driving conditions. Speed limits or closures may be put in place. 
‚Ä¢ Wildfire smoke affects people differently. People with pre-existing health conditions or sensitivities to air pollution are at risk of worsened symptoms from smoke exposure. For smoke and air quality alerts visit: www.airhealth.ca 

WHAT‚ÄôS OPEN AND CLOSED‚Ä¶ 
‚Ä¢ Waterton Lakes National Park is Closed: www.parkscanada.ca/waterton-kenow-fire 
‚Ä¢ Calgary Forest Protection Area south of Highway 532 is Closed: http://srd.web.alberta.ca/calgary-area-update

To subscribe or unsubscribe to these updates contact the Fire Information Officer assistant at elisabeth.caron@pc.gc.ca or 819-247-0075. For media inquiries contact the Fire Information Officer at john.stoesser@pc.gc.ca or 403-859-5127. For general inquiries, call our Information Line at 403-859-5109 or kenowfire.waterton@pc.gc.ca

http://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/ab/waterton/securite-safety/feu-fire-kenow

Kenow Fire - Waterton Lakes National Park: September 8, 2017; 19:15hr
Parks Canada and RCMP have safely evacuated all residents and non-essential personnel from the park. The Waterton townsite is secured. Admittance at the gate is limited to essential personnel. Intense fire behavior and low visibility caused a risk to safety. To ensure safety, Parks Canada evacuated Waterton.  We understand this is a stressful situation and thank everyone for their cooperation, making this a safe and efficient evacuation process.
The fire did not cross Sage Pass or South Kootenay Pass into the park and helicopters were able to bucket water later in the afternoon. Fire crews enhanced Waterton‚Äôs infrastructure and facility protection. Yesterday afternoon we successfully burned out approximately 30 hectares of vegetation near South Kootenay Pass, removing this fuel in anticipation of increasing wind and fire behaviour today. Burning these fuels under calmer conditions increased our chances of holding the fire at this location. Weather conditions are expected to increase fire behaviour for the next two days:
http://www.pc.gc.ca/apps/scond/cond_e.asp?oid=29170&opark=100429

During the mid-16th century, large numbers of right and bowhead whales drew whalers from the Basque region of Spain and France to the Strait of Belle Isle, where they established a major whaling port at Red Bay. For some 70 years, Basque whalers made the dangerous, month-long journey across the Atlantic to hunt whales and produce the oil that lit the lamps of Europe. See original Basque artifacts, remains, and restored chalupa at Red Bay National Historic Site in Newfoundland.

On this day in 1966 four Caterpillar tractors began dragging the 1,300-ton S.S. Klondike II from the Whitehorse shipyards to her current location next to the river at the far end of town. Over eight tons of Palmolive Princess Snow Flake soap lubricated the steel cradle and wooden skids on which she moved. It took 5 weeks to complete the move! Now restored to her original 1937 appearance, the S.S. Klondike was designated a National Historic Site in 1967.

This V-E Day, we‚Äôre remembering the #HomeportHeroes who served in Canada‚Äôs Merchant Navy and aided Allied victory in the Second World War. 

From December 1941 until the end of the war in 1945, Canadian shipyards on both coasts, and along the St. Lawrence River, undertook a massive emergency shipbuilding campaign to deliver hundreds of desperately-needed vessels to support the Allied war effort. Naval ships like destroyer HMCS Haida National Historic Site escorted merchant convoys to protect against submarine and air attacks. #LestWeForget http://ow.ly/79eS30brkUz

Presentation swords like this one are decorative, and were most often presented as gifts for impressive achievements, to be worn on special occasions. This sword was presented by the Legislature of Upper Canada in 1816 in recognition of Lieutenant-Colonel Francis Battersby's services. He was a British Commander who served during the War of 1812.

The Fenian Brotherhood was formed in the United States in 1858. They sought independence for Ireland from Britain and the establishment of an Irish Republic. The American Fenians planned a series of raids to seize the transportation network of Canada, in order to force the British to exchange Ireland‚Äôs freedom for possession of Canada. They planned and partly executed raids in Ontario, Quebec, Manitoba and the Maritimes in 1866, 1870 and 1871. This extremely rare example of a Fenian jacket was taken from a Fenian prisoner in Quebec in May of 1870. 

Discover more artefacts under our care by following #OurVaults on @PCarchaeology. https://twitter.com/pcarchaeology

The Blanding‚Äôs turtle is a medium-sized freshwater turtle, which is readily distinguished by its bright yellow throat and chin. They typically live a very long life (80+ years).  
We have taken concrete action at several of our national parks including Kejimkujik National Park in Nova Scotia, and Point Pelee and Georgian Bay Islands National Parks and more recently, in Rouge National Urban Park in Ontario to protect and restore Blanding Turtles and their habitat.  

Follow our tips on how to interact with #wildlife in our parks: http://ow.ly/INcO30aFLy9

The beluga whale, nicknamed the ‚Äúsea canary‚Äù because of its diverse and frequent vocalisations, is a fascinating species which lives in a complex social structure.  With its white skin, prominent forehead and lack of dorsal fin, it is easily recognizable among marine mammals. The St. Lawrence beluga is a year-round resident of the St. Lawrence River and depends on the Saguenay-St. Lawrence Marine Park to feed and rear its young.  

We are working with the Department of Fisheries and Oceans and others to encourage the recovery of this endangered species by enhancing protection of its critical habitat. Awareness campaigns, patrolling and new regulations have reduced the threats on belugas caused by boat traffic.

Follow our tips on how to interact with #wildlife in our parks: http://ow.ly/INcO30aFLy9

Ancient Murrelets (or Night Birds in the Haida language) ‚Äì are a handsome black and white seabird of the North Pacific:  the "penguin" of Canada. Ancient Murrelet colonies in Gwaii Haanas are threatened by invasive rats that arrived with the first sailing ships. These birds are a barometer of the health, both of the marine ecosystems and the remote islands on which they breed. 
With the Haida Nation and several Canadian and international partners, we have successfully restored breeding habitat for the Ancient Murrelet on three islands.

Follow our tips on how to interact with #wildlife in our parks: http://ow.ly/INcO30aFLy9

The Northern Leopard Frog has a very distinctive call that sounds like a door creaking open, followed by a little chuckle sound.  Once the most wide-spread frog in North America, it started to mysteriously disappear from much of southwestern Canada, including Waterton Lakes National Park in Alberta, in the late 1970s. 

We are taking northern leopard frog egg masses from Grasslands National Park, where the frog populations are healthy, and bringing them back to Waterton Lakes.  Our scientists are also working alongside the Calgary Zoological Society to take the search for the missing frogs to the genetic level using an innovative environmental DNA (eDNA) monitoring technique.  

Follow our tips on how to interact with #wildlife in our parks: http://ow.ly/INcO30aFLy9

The vast majority of whoopers breed in Wood Buffalo National Park, located along the border of Alberta and the Northwest Territories, and they winter only in a small marsh on the coast of Texas.  
We have been working with partners for 50 years to protect their important nesting habitat within Wood Buffalo National Park and to date, our data shows that these recovery efforts are working!

Jasper National Park has five peaks named after Victoria Cross recipients with connections to Alberta, including Mount Pattison, dedicated to Private John G. Pattison. In 1917, Pattison singlehandedly overtook an enemy machine gun during the Battle of #Vimy Ridge. #Vimy100

An unforgettable tribute to the centennial of the Battle of Vimy Ridge took place at Fort Rodd Hill National Historic Site last night. Parks Canada honoured the historic victory, achieved through great sacrifice, as 10,500 soldiers were killed, wounded, or went missing after the battle. #Vimy100

Tomorrow is Auyuittuq's birthday! Well, the anniversary of its creation as a national park. The most accessible of the Nunavut parks, its raw beauty can also be experienced on a spring snowmobile day-trip to the Arctic Circle or summer hike to Ulu Peak. Did you know the Inuktitut word "auyuittuq" means "the land that never melts"? Even so, it's famous for its stunning blooming season in July and early August. Plan your visit: http://ow.ly/2Hcw30aczlb Parks Canada Nunavut

Lester B. Pearson ‚Äì our country‚Äôs 14th Prime Minister ‚Äì was a world statesman and a proud Canadian. He is someone who left a larger-than-life mark, not only on Canada, but on the global community. Two plaques commemorating some of his achievements were unveiled and the former prime minister was honoured as a person of national historic significance.

At 44,807 km2, Wood Buffalo National Park is Canada‚Äôs largest national park and one of the largest in the world! The park was established in 1922 to protect the free-roaming bison herds of the area. Today, the park supports and protects many unique natural and cultural resources, like the nesting habitat of the last remaining wild migratory flock of whooping cranes left in the world.

Located on a peninsula jutting out into Lake Erie, Point Pelee is not only the southernmost national park in Canada, it‚Äôs the very southern tip of the country itself. Point Pelee is also home to a whopping 66 species at risk ‚Äì more than any other national park in the country. This includes the monarch butterfly, a species threaten by extreme weather and habitat loss. Point Pelee is working to restore the savannah areas that provide vital habitat for the monarch. #LearnAboutButterfliesDay

Happy birthday to Elk Island National Park!  

With elk, mule deer and moose enclosed within its fenced boundaries, Elk Park became the first federally controlled area in Canada to be enclosed as a big game sanctuary. Elk Island Park, as it was called in 1908, was a wildlife park until it became formally designated as a Dominion Park on this day in 1913!

All her life, Katharine McLennan nurtured a deep passion and commitment towards the history and preservation of the Fortress of Louisbourg in Cape Breton, where she was from. For years, she did extensive research to help tell the story of Louisbourg, and, after World War I, she was at the forefront of a civil group aiming to preserve the Fortress of Louisbourg site. Their work led to the opening of the Louisbourg Museum in 1936 and the partial reconstruction of the Fortress in the 1960s. Katharine was named "Honorary Curator" of the museum and served in this capacity for over twenty years. #EqualityMatters #InternationalWomensDay

It's Unique Names Day! There are many national parks with very special (and sometimes hard to say) names, like Kouchibouguac National Park. Pronounced koo-she-boo-gwak, it means "river of long tides" in Mi'kmaq, where fresh and salt water meet. Learn more about what's in the names of our national parks: http://ow.ly/xane3093WWd

It‚Äôs National Frozen Food Day! Did you know flash-freezing technology was inspired by Inuit ice-fishing practices in Canada? Rock caches are a traditional means of storing food in the North. Natural gaps in between rocks channel air flow, acting like a coolant, to keep food fresh or frozen. Tuktut Nogait National Park is home to an area called ‚ÄúMany Caches,‚Äù where you can find, you guessed it, many, many caches! Who knew areas like this are to thank for your modern-day frozen dinners!

It's #NamesakeDay! Did you know that many of our national historic forts and national parks have namesake merchant vessels? Among others, Banff Park, Cape Breton, and Green Gables Park, named quite evidently after one of Canada's most popular heroines! These vessels contributed to securing Allied victory in 1945, a legacy with which Parks Canada is proud to associate.

Hey #Toronto! Join us at Rouge National Urban Park for #BioBlitz Canada June 24-25 from noon until noon and help us count and celebrate the amazing diversity of life found across Canada! A BioBlitz is an event that focuses on finding and identifying as many species as possible in a specific area over a short period of time. At a BioBlitz, scientists, families, students, teachers, and other community members work together to get an overall count of the plants, animals, fungi, and other organisms that live in a place. Registration for scientists and skilled naturalists is now open! For folks of all ages wanting to learn more identification and field work skills, registration for Guided Bioblitz sessions opens March 21.
To register as a scientist visit www.ontariobioblitz.ca. The Rouge is hosting one of 30 Bioblitz events happening across the country as part of Canada 150 celebrations. Visit www.bioblitzcanada.ca to find a Bioblitz near you!
A special thanks to our event partners - Royal Ontario Museum, Canadian Wildlife Federation, The Toronto Zoo, BIObus_Canada, and Toronto and Region Conservation (TRCA).

We invite you to explore the Chilkoot Trail NHS! A centuries old path first crossed by Chilkoot Tlingit traders and later stormed by the Klondike Gold Rush stampeders. The Chilkoot Trail starts at tidewater in Dyea, Alaska and ends on the shores of the Southern Lakes headwaters of the mighty Yukon River. Few trails of similar length offer more dramatic changes in climate, terrain and vegetation or more spectacular scenery.

It's time for #TriviaTuesday! This isolated post was a vital fur trade hub for more than 250 years... What is it called? #NHS100

ANSWER: It's York Factory National Historic Site in Manitoba! Between 1684 and its closing 273 years later in 1957, York Factory served as a trading post. From 1812 to the late 1850s, it was also the main entry point for European immigration to Western Canada.

Parks Canada is excited about the reports of the discovery of the wreck of HMS Terror. 

The discovery of HMS Terror would be important for Inuit communities and Canada, reflecting the ongoing and valuable role of Inuit traditional knowledge in the search and making a significant contribution to completing the Franklin story. 

Parks Canada is currently working with our partners to validate the details of the discovery.

Here‚Äôs another #EnviroWeek camping hack to cut down on camping waste! Find yourself bringing lots of gear to prepare your camping meals? Take a bit of time to prep your food at home before you go! Packing pre-chopped veggies or cracking eggs into a mason jar before you go means more time to enjoy your camping trip, more fuel for your compost at home, and less to carry around!

Did you know Banff National Park created a special refuge for a species at risk ‚Äì the westslope cutthroat trout? 

In Alberta alone, westslope cutthroat trout occupy less than 10% of their historical range. Westslope cutthroat trout remain in only about 55 small locations in Alberta, ten of which are in Banff National Park. Parks Canada is therefore an important partner in recovery efforts for this species! Learn more: http://ow.ly/KJWbQ #WildlifeWednesday

Did you know Bio-Blitzes help us learn more about the flora and fauna in our parks AND species at risk? You are invited to Fundy National Park's #BioBlitz in June. Help us record as many different species as possible!

On #WorldFishMigrationDay, we highlight the American Eel!
This eel faces a number of threats, such as obstacles in freshwater preventing its upstream migration, mortality due to hydroelectric power plant turbines, fisheries, contaminants, swim bladder parasites, climate change and changes in ocean conditions. Collecting data in order to properly assess the American Eel's status has become a necessity: http://ow.ly/PWSC300i9XU World Fish Migration Day #SpeciesAtRisk #FishMigration #WFMD2016

Happy World Wildlife Day! #FunFact: To protect whales, such as the St. Lawrence beluga and the blue whale, our staff has been studying... their food!

Why? To identify feeding grounds. The findings were then used to inform the shipping industry, who agreed to reduce the speed of vessels in the main feeding grounds in order to reduce the risk of collisions with whales. This is a great example of how Parks Canada is leading by using science to support wildlife protection.

To learn more about this initiative and other Parks Canada species at risk success stories, visit our website: http://www.pc.gc.ca/eng/nature/eep-sar/itm11.aspx.

Have you ever tried snowshoeing? 

Here are 8 reasons why you should:
1) No or very little coordination is required. It‚Äôs simple to learn for all ages!
2) Little preparation time needed before leaving on a hike.
3) There‚Äôs low risk of injury and it‚Äôs easy on joints.
4) It‚Äôs a superior calorie-burner - about 500/hour.
5) It provides a great legs and buttocks workout - and arms too, if you add poles.
6) You can explore out-of-the-way places.
7) Snowshoeing is inexpensive - especially compared with other winter sports.
8) It's so much fun!!!

This coming Monday is the most exciting day of the year at Elk Island National Park - the start of Plains Bison handling.

Over three hundred bison will be weighed, aged, tagged and we‚Äôll sample blood, hair and stool... it‚Äôs even more fun than it sounds!

status_message: Explore winter in different national parks. Torngat Mountains is a magnificent land shaped by time and spirit: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FVLmL9Aqi7o

Happy Camcorder Day!

Perhaps you're a professional who enjoys shooting the beauty of nature, or an extreme sports fan who attaches a GoPro to their helmet before going down the slopes. Or maybe you just like recording memories that can be cherished forever!

Either way, get out there and get filming... we want to see your best nature shots!

Ready, set, camp! It's time to reserve your summer campsites!

Visit our site for details and specific date and time that reservations launch for each location:  http://www.pc.gc.ca/eng/voyage-travel/reserve.aspx 

Today you can book an oTENTik at Fort Langley National Historic Site and Fort Rodd Hill and Fisgard Lighthouse National Historic Sites or a front country camping adventure at Gulf Islands National Park Reserve! #2016camping

Happy New Year!!!
We are starting 2016 with great news: as a first step towards celebrating Canada's 150th Anniversary of Confederation at Parks Canada places, our 2016 Discovery Pass will be valid for 24 months!

The Discovery Pass gives you unlimited opportunities to enjoy nearly 200 National Parks, National Historic Sites and National Marine Conservation Areas across Canada. Find out more: http://ow.ly/WgNJc

2015 is already behind us! These images recall the best underwater archaeology moments of the year at Parks Canada: a marine biology pilot project, a mission under the Arctic ice, including a video guided tour of the wreck of HMS Erebus, and dozens of artefacts to analyse.

Today is a perfect time to hang out in our #FranklinExpedition web section: http://www.pc.gc.ca/eng/culture/franklin/index.aspx

Winter camping??? Of course, we're Canadian! 
Winter is a great #TimeToConnect with the great outdoors and find your inner adventurer.

Check our website to find out which parks offer winter camping, and book your #2016Camping experience soon: http://ow.ly/UEXWU Tourism Industry Association of Canada
